This was my justification in the probability history which seems counter-intuitive as there are many ways that demonstrations could arise, but the events usually they simmer and have a strategy behind them.  There are many reasons for riots and protests which are not forecasted as these activities generally flare for unexpected reasons on many levels. Although there are areas of the world where protests are ongoing (1), and have become threads in the fabric of society, there are those which are possible but not necessarily expected due to one event within a construct of tension (2), or areas that have a library of complaints against others (3),  and use events to demonstrate or riot. A person could have been run over by someone from another religion or tribe which could lead to demonstrations, or a leader of a group who denounces others, or someone viewed as being taken in by police. 
These demonstration may have ulterior motives which have nothing to do with an event, such as toppling a government or gaining religious, tribal, labor, monetary, or political leverage through popular dissent. These are some of the issues in Cote d' Ivory which could cause a demonstration.

The IC had 32 riots out of  84 events in the data set pulled.  There were 0 riots recorded in the IC during the month of August.  That said, the prior probability of a riot occurring in August was given 1% based on the data.  The probability of a riot happening out all events on any date within the IC borders is .38.  Trying to use bayes, states the probability of a riot occurring in August of 2017 on the Ivory Coast is 4%.  This prediction is also taking @dcm forecast's reasons in account.

ACLED data shows that August is consistently the lowest month for protests, though there has been some volatility there.  The issues at the heart of that are being addressed at least in short term - back pay to several groups, particularly those in the military/mutiny, efforts to introduce some reforms to limit cost of living increases and protect farmers and other workers (since one of the common tension points seems to be economic success in many areas while poverty/poor wages/poor back pay for public servants and workers in other areas = frustration & resentment).  Based on comments in interviews & local news websites, there seems to be a lot of skepticism about how long that will last and how much good these placating measures will do, but no expectation of violence erupting.  There has also been ongoing/recent activity concerning the 2020 election calling on supporters to back candidates based on loyalties and connections to previous parties where there are very deep divides.

Approximately 80% of the riots/protests recorded in the ACLED database for this year relate to the military and pay: http://www.acleddata.com/data/realtime-data/   Beyond this there are occasional, one-off protests (school teachers, journalists, cocoa farmers).  It is not clear that the bonuses dispute has concluded satisfactorily for soldiers, although the chances of it bubbling up again in the next nineteen days are unclear.  Nonetheless between soldiers, ex-soldiers and occasional disputes, it seems unlikely to me that there will not be some kind of protest before the end of August, given the base rates other posters have mentioned.

1. Unrest among former civil war combatants is increasing due to poor integration into society and job prospects. 
2. Mutinities of military units indicate increasing unrest over pay. Although mutinities due not fall under the category riots and protests, they indicate a general sense of dissatisfaction. 
3. In July, a police academy was attacked and weapons were stolen.
4. Regular reports of riots and protests during this year.

ACLED has recorded at least one riot/protest event in Ivory Coast every month this year. While the tempo has certainly slowed down since the mutiny earlier this year, I think the basic theme of at least one incident per month continues. Looking historically, there haven't been protests every year but there have been several in August of 2015 and 2016.
Most months this year have had riots/protests. July appears to be the exception to the rule.

Since 1997 there have been 8 years in which in the month of August there has been at least one riot or protest. 14 out of 19 riots or protests took place in the second half of the month. Over the last 10 years there have been 6 years in which there has been at least 1 protest or riot in month of August. August last year there have been 7! riots or protests in August all in the second half of the month. The way I see it there is >40% base rate chance a riot or protest will happen this year. Also should riot(s) or protest(s) occur this year there is > 70% chance it will happen after the Aug 15. We'll see :)
There are tensions however, the time of the year is not conducive for riots. If protests erupt, it may be along existing event of another kind hence, not out of question but not likely.
